The core of the struggle for free,\nafe abortion is the same as all liberation struggles: freedom from control, coercion, and exploitation.

The Black mortality rate, family separation, pipelines to mass incarceration, deportation -- these are all reproductive justice issues.\n\nThat‚Äôs why we fight for police-free schools, gender-affirming healthcare, housing as a human right, environmental justice, and many other aims.

Affirming, free and safe abortion care must be honored as a human right.\n\nFor communities of color, however, reproductive justice hasn‚Äôt always meant only fighting for the right to an abortion, it has also meant to fight for the right to have and to parent our children.

‚Ä¶our newly arrived neighbors who have fled from horrific conditions all too often benefitting ‚Äì or even created by ‚Äì the policies of the US government and the practices of US corporations.

13/13

To be sure, that will require financial support from Albany and especially Washington. We all have an obligation to band together and provide supportive foundations for‚Ä¶

12/13

In order to grow the economy, expand the tax base, and fulfill our highest aspirations for our city, we must invest in the means of a dignified life: securing our newest neighbors jobs, care, education, and permanent housing.

11/13

I wholeheartedly agree with NYC Comptroller Brad Lander that merely providing emergency shelter is a short-sighted use of public funds.

10/13

While I continue to press for more humane conditions at respite centers, we must also advocate for more sustainable, long term solutions (and supports) for our newly arrived neighbors.

9/13

Moving forward, the Mayor‚Äôs Administration must prioritize expanding and expediting the appointment process for NYC IDs so that our newly arrived neighbors can move out of respite centers with opportunity and dignity. 

8/13

Obtaining legal identification is a critical step in asylum seekers‚Äô safe transition out of respite centers.

7/13

Notably, the lack of consistent support from case workers poses a challenge to asylum seekers accessing critical services in order to transition out of the center. A particularly glaring challenge is our city‚Äôs inability to process NYC IDs in a timely & efficient manner.

6/13

I had the privilege of meeting with the skilled, compassionate on-site staff who work tirelessly to create a supportive environment for residents despite the lack of sufficient resources and space. Of particular concern is the lack of on-site showers.

5/13

The conditions at St. Margaret Mary, while safe for temporary residents, are neither acceptable nor sustainable.

4/13

Let me say this unequivocally: We need to do better by our new arrivals. Welcoming refugees and migrants from around the world with open arms is one of this city‚Äôs proudest traditions. The current moment calls us to rise to that legacy with great urgency.

3/13

Without a jury, it‚Äôs a judge hearing cops testimony & playing role of the jury. Only way a not guilty verdict is returned is if judge says cop is lying. Almost NEVER happens. Cases juries would find reasonable doubt & acquit instead end up being rubber stamped guilty verdicts.

Here‚Äôs the really big prosecutorial advantage & injustice. If it goes to trial, they drop the A misd solely to deny a person a trial by a jury of their peers. Usually in these low level misdemeanor cases the *only* witness to testify is a police officer...

First they get to manipulate speedy trial rules. A misdemeanors allow the DA 90 days to make their case, while B Misd only allow them 60 days. 30 extra days to destabilize a persons life and potentially coerce a plea because of the destabilization.

This is huge. Here‚Äôs how the B misdemeanor jury trial rule is manipulated: Your client is charged w both an A misd & a B misd. From Day 1 the DA knows they will pursue the top A misd charge only until the eve of trial, then drop that charge & only go forward on the B misd. Why?‚Ä¶

Our public safety plan would empower people, not police, to lead with care and keep our communities safe. It would fully fund public health infrastructure and community stability.

You can find it here: https://t.co/ePGKU4P6tC

Incarceration and over policing have always unfairly targeted our Black, brown, and poor communities.
 
"Tough on crime" policies do not keep us safe. They destroy lives. They perpetuate poverty and systemic racism, which breed violence.

Here in Dist 22 we have 800+ people in our shelters. Many can't access mental healthcare as we don't have enough accessible hospitals & clinics to provide those services.
 
Instead, we have the largest mental health provider in the state in our backyard: Rikers Island.

We have to house people, rather than leave them vulnerable on our streets and subways. 
 
We have to provide mental healthcare and invest in preventing harm before it happens.

The over 4000 subway cops didn't prevent this tragedy & 500 more won't either.

Police respond to violence ‚Äì evidence shows they do not create accountability or prevent future violence.

It‚Äôs devastating people experiencing homelessness were hurt & two more killed in our subways recently. 

It‚Äôs even more devastating that the City's response - 500 more cops in the subway - won‚Äôt keep us safe, & won‚Äôt prevent this from happening again.

Police do not create public safety ‚Äì community investments in health & stability do. Calling for more cops & cages in response to spikes in violence perpetuate the status quo - the mass incarceration of 2.3m people & 1000+ killings by police annually. https://t.co/5CzMohqqoH

The provisions in this bill are common sense, cost-effective strategies for an NYC with greater economic prosperity, public safety and public health, more racial and gender equity, and more care and compassion.

6. Groundwork for Futher Legislation

Establish a definition for sex work in the administrative code, as a framework for further legislation relating to the field.

5. Right to Privacy

Establish employment in sex work in the administrative code's privacy laws as one of the categories of identifying information that cannot be shared

4. Report on Sex Worker Family Policing

Require the Admin for Children's Services (ACS) to report on outcomes of investigations the agency initiated during the prior calendar year in which case workers used information related to a person's involvement in the sex industry.

3. Prohibit Housing Discrimination

Prohibit landlords from discrimination against a prospective tenant on the basis of current or past sex work.

2. Know Your Rights

Create a board within the Department of Consumer and Worker Protection (DCWP) tasked with supporting sex workers to know their rights in relation to specific workplace issues they are particularly likely to face, like wage theft.

In the bill:

1. Sex Worker Opportunity Program

Establish a program for awarding grants to community organizations that work directly with sex workers, to provide economic support for mobility, health, housing, and social well-being.
And let‚Äôs be clear: sex work is work.
No matter why a given person engages in sex work, the city has a responsibility to protect the health, safety, and economic wellbeing of all New Yorkers, regardless of what they do for a living.

In places like Australia and New Zealand, governments have taken this politically thorny issue and established smart, compassionate, evidence-based and human rights-affirming legal frameworks around sex work, and it is time for us to take a first step in the same direction.

Yesterday, alongside @CMCrystalHudson and @nycpa, I introduced a bill to provide for the rights, protection, and economic security of some of our most marginalized, most criminalized, most disrespected neighbors: New Yorkers who engage in sex work.

Doctors, public defenders, families of those who died, formerly & currently incarcerated folks, elected officials, candidates‚Äìwe are raising the alarm, waving red flags, practically begging those w/ authority to hear us: simply being in custody is a potential death sentence.

District Attorneys must stop asking for cash bail, rapidly resolve cases with non-carceral dispositions, and decline to prosecute cases. Judges need to stop sending people to Rikers. Collectively, these actions could save so many lives.

Feigned helplessness will not work here. The Mayor, our District Attorneys, & judges could individually & independently decarcerate Rikers today. The Mayor must exercise power conferred by Correction Law Article 6-A to grant work release to people serving sentences in city jails.

I am deeply frustrated and angry with Mayor Bill de Blasio, the Department of Corrections, judges, and the city‚Äôs five District Attorneys. Our City and State‚Äôs violent and racist carceral system is killing folks, and the power holders who refuse to lift a finger to protect them.
